case_name: State of Punjab v. Khan Chand

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1730 of 1967 filed by State of Punjab against judgment and order dated 24th March 1966 of Punjab High Court in C.W. No. 26 of 1965

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1730 of 1967. From the judgment and order dated the 24th March, 1966 of the Punjab High Court in C.W. No. 26 of 1965

facts.text: Punjab High Court Full Bench struck down section 2 of East Punjab Movable Property Requisitioning Act 1947 as violative of Article 14

anchor.surface_text: against a Full Bench judgment of the Punjab High Court whereby section 2 of the East Punjab Movable Property  Requisitioning  Act, 1947  East Punjab Act XV of 1947   hereinafter referred

facts.text: Punjab High Court held section 2 not severable from rest of Act and entire Act unconstitutional

anchor.surface_text: to as the Act  was struck down on the ground of being violative article 14 of the Constitution. It was further held that section 2 was number severable from the rest of the Act

facts.text: Respondent in civil appeal No. 1730 is owner of Tata Mercedes Benz truck No. 1607

anchor.surface_text: We may set out the facts giving rise to civil appeal No. 1730, because it is the companymon case of the parties that the decision in that appeal would govern the other three appeals also. The respondent

facts.text: District Magistrate Rohtak passed order under section 2 on December 18 1964 requiring Khan Chand to place truck at disposal of Executive Engineer Rohtak for famine work

anchor.surface_text: On December 18, 1964 the District Magistrate Rohtak passed an order under section 2 of the Act requiring Khan Chand respondent to place the above truck at the disposal of the Executive Engineer Rohtak because the District Magistrate was of the view that trucks were necessary to carry road material for famine work.

facts.text: Truck taken into possession by District Magistrate on December 19 1964

anchor.surface_text: It was also mentioned that companypensation for the use of the truck would be paid at the rate fixed by the Government. The truck was thereafter taken into possession by the District Magistrate or December 19, 1964.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Article 226 in High Court challenging validity of District Magistrate's order and provisions of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed petition under article 226 of the Constitution in the High Court challenging the validity of the above order of the District Magistrate. Prayer was also made to declare the, provisions of the Act to be unconstitutional

facts.text: Petition resisted by State of Punjab and District Magistrate Rohtak with affidavit filed

anchor.surface_text: The petition was resisted by the State of Punjab and the District Magistrate of Rohtak, who are the appellants before us, and the affidavit of the District Magistrate was filed in opposition to the petition.

facts.text: High Court single Judge referred petition to Division Bench

anchor.surface_text: The petition was first posted for hearing before a single Judge who referred it to a Division Bench.

facts.text: Division Bench referred petition to Full Bench due to importance

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench, it view of the importance of the matter, referred it to Full Bench.

facts.text: Full Bench held section 2 gives unfettered power violating Article 14

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench examined the different provisions of the Act and found that section 2 of the Act was violative of article 14 of the Constitution as it gave unfettered and unguided power to the executive to interfere with the property rights of the citizen-, in an arbitrary manner.

facts.text: Act replaced Ordinance V of 1947 promulgated by Governor of East Punjab on September 15 1947

anchor.surface_text: The Act, it may be stated replaced Ordinance V of 1947 which had been promulgated by the Governor of East Punjab on September 15, 1947.

facts.text: Act first published in East Punjab Government Gazette on December 13 1947

anchor.surface_text: The Act was first published in the East Punjab Government Gazette on December 13, 1947.

facts.text: Preamble of Act provides for requisitioning and acquisition of movable property

anchor.surface_text: According to the preamble it was an Act to provide for the requisitioning and acquisition movable property.

facts.text: Supreme Court majority held section 2 confers uncontrolled power without guidelines violating Article 14

anchor.surface_text: This companytention, in our opinion, is number well founded. The relevant provisions of the Act have been reproduced above and from a perusal thereof we find that the Act companyfers uncontrolled power on the State Government or the officers authorised by it to requisition any movable property.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed appeals with costs

anchor.surface_text: There is numbermerit in these appeals which accordingly fail and are dismissed with companyts. One set of hearing fee.

facts.text: K.K. Mathew J gave dissenting opinion upholding section 2

anchor.surface_text: KHANNA, J.-... K. K. Mathew, J gave a dissenting Opinion.

holdings.text: Section 2 of the Act vitiates Article 14 due to total absence of guidelines for exercise of power of requisitioning, conferring arbitrary and uncontrolled power.

anchor.surface_text: The total absence of guidelines for the exercise of power of requisitioning of movable property, in our opinion, vitiates section 2 of the Act. Arbitrariness and the power to discriminate are writ large on the face of the said provision of the Act and, in our opinion, that provision falls within the mischief which article 14 of the Constitution is designed to prevent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act confers uncontrolled power without purpose, policy or guidelines; delegation to any officer possible; leads to discrimination; applies Dalmia principle requiring guidelines for discretion.

holdings.text: Section 2 is not severable from the rest of the Act; entire Act unconstitutional as other provisions ancillary to requisition power under sections 2 and 3.

anchor.surface_text: It was further held that section 2 was not severable from the rest of the Act and the other provisions of the Act were merely ancillary to the powers of requisitioning and acquisition of property contained in sections 2 and 3 of the Act. The High Court accordingly held the entire Act to be unconstitutional and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding accepted; s3 requires s2 invocation; other sections ancillary; cannot operate independently.

anchor.surface_text: As the Act was found to confer on the Government arbitrary and uncontrolled power to discriminate both between things and persons and as the discrimination was writ large on the face of the Act, the entire Act was held to be unconstitutional and void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from non-severability of s2; upholds High Court.

holdings.text: Pre-Constitution laws not immune from Article 14 challenge; Article 31(5) protects only against Article 31(2) challenges.

anchor.surface_text: The protection afforded by article 31(5) to pre-Constitution laws is against the challenge on the ground of contravention of article 31(2) article 31(5) gives no immunity to pre-Constitution laws from attack on the ground that they violate article 14 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Art 31(5); applies to impugned Act.

holdings.text: Requisitioning under section 2 not for public purpose; cannot read 'public purpose' into section 2.

anchor.surface_text: We find it difficult to accede to the contention that the requisitioning of movable property contemplated by section 2 of the Act is requisitioning of such property for a public purpose. The words for a public purpose do not find a mention in section 2

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express mention; judicial legislation impermissible; contrasts with other statutes like Land Acquisition Act.

holdings.text: Act confers arbitrary uncontrolled power enabling discrimination between persons/things similarly situate.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench examined the different provisions of the Act and found that section 2 of the Act was violative of article 14 of the Constitution as it gave unfettered and unguided power to the executive to interfere with the property rights of the citizen-, in an arbitrary manner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No guidelines/policy; power for any purpose; upheld High Court.

holdings.text: Both conditions of Pannalal Binjraj test satisfied: possibility of real/substantial discrimination and impingement on fundamental right.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court in the present case, in our opinion, can be sustained because both the conditions laid down above have been satisfied. There is every possibility of real and substantial discrimination under the impugned Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Pannalal: discrimination possible; affects property right.

anchor.surface_text: The ultimate question in these appeals is whether the provisions of s.2 of the East Punjab Movable Property Requisitioning Act, 1947 ... violate article 14 of the Constitution and are, therefore, bad.

holdings.text: Appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: There is no merit in these appeals which accordingly fail and are dismissed with costs. One set of hearing fee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No merit; upholds High Court on constitutionality.

holdings.text: Enactments conferring discretion must prescribe guidelines to avoid Article 14 violation; uncontrolled discretion degenerates into arbitrariness.

anchor.surface_text: What is objectionable is the conferment of arbitrary and uncontrolled discretion without any guidelines whatsoever with regard to the exercise of that discretion. ... Discretion which is absolute uncontrolled and without any guidelines in the exercise of the powers

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle from Dalmia; applies to requisition power.

precedents.citation: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar Ors.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar Ors.  1  that a statute may number make any classification of the persons or things for the purpose of applying its provisions but may leave it to the discretion of the Government to select and classify persons or things to whom its provisions are to apply.

precedents.case_name: Ram Krishna Dalmia v Justice S R Tendolkar
precedents.cited_proposition: a statute may not make any classification [...] the discrimination is inherent in the statute itself
precedents.cited_holding: the court will strike down the statute if it does not lay down any principle or policy for guiding the exercise of discretion by the Government in the matter of selection or classification

precedents.citation: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India

anchor.surface_text: Pannalal Binjraj v. Union of India 1 , which has been referred to by Mr. Mahajan. In that case this Court upheld the constitutional validity of section 5 7-A  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 and held that the power vested in the Commissioner of income Tax or the Central Board of Revenue to transfer income-tax cases outside the area where the assessed resided or carried on business would not amount to a denial of equality before the law.

precedents.case_name: Pannalal Binjraj v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between discretion regarding fundamental rights and other rights; transfer of cases does not violate Art 14

precedents.citation: Jayantilal Parshottamdas v. State of Gujarat

anchor.surface_text: Jayantilal Parshottamdas v. State of Gujarat, 1  but as pointed out above, we find no specifications of any purpose at all in the section.

precedents.case_name: Jayantilal Parshottamdas v State of Gujarat
precedents.cited_proposition: section sustainable if purpose specified as public purpose

precedents.citation: Harishankar Bagla Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Harishankar Bagla Anr. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 2 , this Court upheld the validity of sections 3, 4 and 6 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946.

precedents.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: legislature must declare policy and provide standard to guide execution
precedents.cited_holding: policy laid down in Essential Supplies Act for supply of commodities

precedents.citation: Sri Ram Ram Narain Medhi v. The State of Bombay

precedents.case_name: Ram Narain Medhi v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: where legislature settles policy and principles, delegation of details ok

precedents.case_name: P J Irani v State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: guidance from preamble and provisions for exemption power

precedents.case_name: Gurbachan Singh v State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: discretionary power upheld when vested in high ranking authorities

anchor.surface_text: Virendra v. State of Punjab 3 , Das, C.J. said In the first place, the discretion is given in the first instance to the State Government itself

precedents.cited_proposition: vesting discretion in State Govt or high dignitary is safeguard

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v P N Balsara

precedents.cited_holding: Art 14 invoked only if real discrimination and impinges on fundamental right

anchor.surface_text: The total absence of guidelines for the exercise of power of requisitioning of movable property, in our opinion, vitiates section 2 of the Act. Arbitrariness and the power to discriminate are writ large on the face of the said provision of the Act and, in our opinion, that provision falls within the mischief which article 14 of the Constitution is designed to prevent.
ORDER In accordance with the decision of the majority, the appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: It was further held that section 2 was not severable from the rest of the Act and the other provisions of the Act were merely ancillary to the powers of requisitioning and acquisition of property contained in sections 2 and 3 of the Act. The High Court accordingly held the entire Act to be unconstitutional and void.
ORDER In accordance with the decision of the majority, the appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: As the Act was found to confer on the Government arbitrary and uncontrolled power to discriminate both between things and persons and as the discrimination was writ large on the face of the Act, the entire Act was held to be unconstitutional and void.
ORDER In accordance with the decision of the majority, the appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The protection afforded by article 31(5) to pre-Constitution laws is against the challenge on the ground of contravention of article 31(2) article 31(5) gives no immunity to pre-Constitution laws from attack on the ground that they violate article 14 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Full Bench examined the different provisions of the Act and found that section 2 of the Act was violative of article 14 of the Constitution as it gave unfettered and unguided power to the executive to interfere with the property rights of the citizen-, in an arbitrary manner.
ORDER In accordance with the decision of the majority, the appeals are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court in the present case, in our opinion, can be sustained because both the conditions laid down above have been satisfied. There is every possibility of real and substantial discrimination under the impugned Act.
ORDER In accordance with the decision of the majority, the appeals are dismissed with costs.

The ultimate question in these appeals is whether the provisions of s.2 of the East Punjab Movable Property Requisitioning Act, 1947 ... violate article 14 of the Constitution and are, therefore, bad.
ORDER In accordance with the decision of the majority, the appeals are dismissed with costs.
